org.gbif.ws.security

Class GbifAppAuthService

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gbif.ws.security.GbifAppAuthService

  • public class GbifAppAuthService
extends Object
    The GBIF authentication scheme is modelled after the Amazon scheme on how to sign REST http requests using a private key. It uses the standard Http Authorization Header to transport the following information: Authorization: GBIF applicationKey:Signature The header starts with the authentication scheme (GBIF), followed by the plain applicationKey and a unique signature for the very request which is generated using a fixed set of request attributes which are then encrypted by a standard HMAC-SHA1 algorithm. A simple GET request with a GBIF header would look like this: 
     GET /name_usage/536123 HTTP/1.1
 Host: johnsmith.s3.amazonaws.com
 Date: Mon, 26 Mar 2007 19:37:58 +0000
 x-gbif-user: trobertson
 x-gbif-date: 16 Mar 2007 19:37:58 GMT
 Authorization: GBIF admin:frJIUN8DYpKDtOLCwo//yllqDzg=
    When signing an http request in addition to the Authentication header some additional custom headers are added which are used to sign and digest the message.
    x-gbif-user is added to transport a proxied user in which the application is acting.
    x-gbif-date is added because there is no way for a jersey client to access the automatically generated date header before the message is actually send.
    x-gbif-content-hash is added similar to the date above hashing the message body if it exists. This will only be for POST/PUT requests instead of using the regular Content-MD5 which cannot be accessed in the jersey client.
